[i]Judgment[/i] takes the foundation of the beloved Yakuza franchise and reinvents it into a gripping, grounded noir-style legal drama ‚Äî one that combines intense action, emotional storytelling, investigative gameplay, and moral complexity without losing the series‚Äô signature style and charm. It‚Äôs one of the finest crime stories RGG Studio has ever delivered.

At the center of the narrative stands Takayuki Yagami ‚Äî a former lawyer turned private detective haunted by one devastating case. His search for redemption becomes the emotional backbone of the story. What starts as a murder investigation spirals into conspiracies that link powerful corporations, the legal system, organized crime, and personal trauma. Yagami isn‚Äôt a fighter because he wants to be ‚Äî he‚Äôs a fighter because the truth demands it.

The supporting cast is exceptional. Kaito serves as both muscle and emotional anchor, bringing loyalty, warmth, and surprising depth. Antagonists are layered and human, driven by ideology rather than cartoonish evil. Every character ‚Äî allies and enemies ‚Äî has purpose, weight, and believable motivations. The longer the mystery unravels, the more you realize there are no easy answers, and morality is never black and white.

Combat is fluid and exhilarating thanks to Yagami‚Äôs martial arts-based fighting styles. Switching between Crane and Tiger styles mid-battle gives every encounter flexibility and identity ‚Äî crowds can be dispatched with sweeping acrobatics while tough opponents demand precise, powerful strikes. Heat actions are fast, stylish, and painful in the best way possible, and boss fights feel personal and cinematic.

What truly sets [i]Judgment[/i] apart is its investigative gameplay. Chasing suspects across rooftops, examining crime scenes, tailing targets, interrogating witnesses, and piecing together evidence through logic and intuition makes the player feel like a detective rather than just a fighter. It blends beautifully with the drama, never feeling gimmicky or forced.

Of course, this is still RGG Studio ‚Äî the world is overflowing with personality. Kamurocho returns in all its neon glory, filled with arcade games, restaurants, Romance of the Three Kingdoms club management, gambling dens, drones, darts, girlfriend relationships, and some of the funniest and most heartfelt side cases ever written. One moment you'll be cracking an impossible murder case; the next you'll be helping a shut-in overcome social fears or dealing with an actor stuck in method acting mode. It‚Äôs chaotic, warm, and endlessly rewarding.

Visually and cinematically, [i]Judgment[/i] stands tall. The Dragon Engine brings gritty atmosphere to every street and alley, but the real magic lies in the direction ‚Äî intense close-ups, emotional monologues, courtroom confrontations, and brooding rain-covered scenes that hit harder than most movies. The soundtrack mixes dark detective tones with high-energy battle themes and emotional orchestral pieces that amplify every major moment.

[i]Judgment[/i] is a masterpiece ‚Äî a legal thriller, a character drama, and an action brawler fused into one unforgettable experience. It carries the spirit of Yakuza while forging its own identity, delivering tension, humor, action, mystery, and heart at a level few games can match.

Takayuki Yagami isn‚Äôt just trying to solve a case ‚Äî he‚Äôs trying to prove that justice still matters in a world determined to bury the truth. And watching him fight for that truth is nothing short of incredible.

Didn't expect much from this series, since I didn't really hear anything good about it aside from some youtube brainrot content. I also wasn't realy thrilled with a new LaD protagonist, so I really thought that it's going to take only a few hours before it would bore me to death. On the grand scheme of things it seemed like yet another Yakuza game - 3rd person brawler that takes place in Kamurocho in requires you to chug Staminians. However...
  First of all - Kamurocho. The city didn't exactly change, it wasn't mowed down and rebuilt from ground up, but the sheer amount of new details brings exactly enough for it to feel lot fresher. Additional courtyards and narrow passages between the building that you can actually traverse now, multi-storey buildings that aren't just empty lifeless husks - it all feels really great.
  Second of all - there are quite a lot of new and revamped old mechanics. Even though sometimes they can overstay it's welcome (like fifth in a row tailing for the last hour) or straight up questionable (extracts? do I have to use them? is the game balanced around them?), it's really nice to see that RGG understands its playerbase sometimes - imagine chases that don't suck? Yeah, it's right there.
  The characters are simply remarkable, they're not just some leeches on Yakuza's legacy - they are in the league of their own and they're not any less cool than a band of OGs. I didn't miss Kiryu or the friendly cyclops through the whole playthrough and it is a huge quality mark in my eyes.
   Lastly, the combat. I would love to say that you have 2 styles here, alas, tha't not the case. RGG forgot to make abilities for the Crane style, so the Tiger outshines it very quickly. The Tiger style also plays different from what I got used to in Yakuza, it's pretty refreshing, though takes some time to understand how to use it efficiently.


Unfortunately, with all that being said, the game's not flawless.
For example, the combat system has a horrible disease - Kiwami 2 syndrome. It wasn't fun in Kiwami 2 to have your strikes bounce off of enemies, it's not fun here either. It becomes worse the more 'elite' an enemy is, with bosses being the worst offenders. I didn't have a lot of trouble fighting big boys, probably because I cheesed the worst fights with a Tiger Drop, but still - they're doable, just mostly unfun and annoying.
Or as another example - a lot of upgradable abilities are hidden behind skill books that you need to find during some of the missions. They are easily missable, and even though they can be bought from an underground trader for a hefty sum of upgrade points, he's not open from the very beginning and you don't really know at what moment you should go and check his assortment. Coupled with abysmal amount of upgrade points you actually receives from random fights and side cases, some of them will never be unlocked. And i'm not talking about some fancy stuff - basic vital stuff such as re-guard and double quickstep is locked away behind 'You need to find a book, idk when or where, just find it man'. It's stupid and I hate it.
You can find a lot more to mald about, but still, it's not that bad, the game is very enjoyable, and the story is good enough to grab you by your cockles and make you dump more and more time into it. I'm overall happy that the series did make it's way to PCs, and if your life is ruined by the Yakuza series as my - you should be happy too.

Judgment, developed by Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio and published by SEGA, is a compelling and stylish action-adventure game that masterfully blends intense detective storytelling with exhilarating combat and open-world exploration. Set in the vibrant yet seedy district of Kamurocho, Tokyo‚Äîa fictionalized version of Kabukicho known for its nightlife and criminal underbelly‚ÄîJudgment takes players on a gripping journey filled with twists, emotional depth, and a captivating cast of characters. As a spin-off from the acclaimed Yakuza series, it both honors and expands upon the studio‚Äôs signature formula, offering something fresh and accessible even for newcomers.

The game centers around Takayuki Yagami, a former defense attorney turned private investigator, who finds himself embroiled in a complex murder case that threatens to unravel the fragile peace of Kamurocho. Unlike the larger-than-life protagonists of traditional crime dramas, Yagami is portrayed with nuance‚Äîgritty, smart, and deeply human. His pursuit of truth is driven by a strong sense of justice but also by personal demons and a desire for redemption. This narrative foundation grounds the game‚Äôs more sensational elements, creating a story that balances drama, intrigue, and moments of levity with great skill.

One of Judgment‚Äôs greatest strengths lies in its storytelling. The plot unfolds through detailed investigations, intense interrogations, and cinematic cutscenes that rival those of high-quality TV dramas or movies. Players must gather evidence, question suspects, and follow leads, turning the game into a detective experience that goes beyond standard action tropes. These investigative sequences are thoughtfully designed, requiring observation, logical thinking, and sometimes creative problem-solving. The writing is sharp and engaging, with a strong supporting cast that brings Kamurocho‚Äôs world to life, including colorful side characters and quirky subplots that add depth and humor without detracting from the main story.

Combat in Judgment is fast-paced and satisfying, borrowing heavily from the Yakuza series but with unique twists to suit Yagami‚Äôs fighting style. Players can switch between two fighting styles on the fly: the balanced Crane Style and the powerful Tiger Style, each offering different moves and strategic options. The combat system is accessible yet deep, rewarding well-timed counters, combos, and environmental interactions like throwing objects or using the environment to gain an advantage. Boss fights and street brawls feel intense and cinematic, providing a welcome break from the investigative pacing. After almost 10 hours focused almost exclusively on the main narrative and a few optional detours (which, according to How Long To Beat, is almost half the length of the entire story), I find myself compelled to drop the game and not recommend it.

And I usually only do that with ones in which I genuinely couldn‚Äôt find enough positive aspects to justify the experience.

In Judgment‚Äôs case, it‚Äôs a perfectly functional game that, at first glance at least, reproduces the franchise‚Äôs particular formula with almost all its elements.

This blend of a cinematic narrative-driven beat ‚Äôem up, set in a small open-world that‚Äôs highly immersive and stuffed with details and side activities to do (from simple minigames to several full classic titles from Sega‚Äôs catalog), wrapped in a complex and very confident tone that contrasts mature and serious themes with completely insane comedic absurdities delivered impeccably, plus an apparently inescapable PS2-era charm in the form of low-production-value sequences and embryonic gameplay ideas that might have been interesting 20 years ago but feel like a bad joke today.

You follow a complex story full of characters, twists and turns, and beat people up in a spectacle of insane brawls. Interspersing your time with small side distractions and eccentric narratives that ultimately celebrate Japanese subcultures.

All the pieces are here, with the series‚Äô trademark quality on full display‚Äîand in all its limitations.

Combat, as always, brings excellent animations, highly impactful and satisfying to watch, but, as always, still has a very low skill ceiling and boils down to button-mashing and abusing the band-aids they added to [i]make it look fair[/i], because they still haven‚Äôt managed to design combat that doesn‚Äôt feel sloppy and immensely inconsistent.

That old joke about the combat basically being slapping people around while chugging energy drinks on an industrial scale to recover your health? Yes, it's still the same thing.

I‚Äôve been trying to find a video of a skilled player demonstrating the potential of these systems in an elegant and satisfying way to watch, but I never do. It‚Äôs always a mess of rules that don‚Äôt work properly and unpredictable results.

At least they finally added a shortcut to use items. Innovation.

The elements added to differentiate this spin-off from the rest of the franchise‚Äîan attempt to sell the idea that you‚Äôre an investigator‚Äîare frankly pitiful.

Interrogation or simple conversation sequences where they pretend they‚Äôre giving you dialogue choices, when in reality all the options are correct or there‚Äôs simply no relevant penalty (when there is one at all) for choosing the wrong one.

Using your phone camera to identify points of interest that the game essentially points out for you. 

Using a drone to identify points of interest, [i]but this time[/i] in higher areas!

Tailing NPCs.

Lockpicking minigames‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs the laziest effort you could find to pretend you‚Äôre getting something resembling actual gameplay. A sketch of an idea that would only make sense in something experimental from the PS2 era, when the franchise was still young and had nothing to compare itself to.

For a franchise that loves padding itself with irrelevant tasks, this feels like a terrible case of [i]Ubisoftitis[/i].

The city is more interconnected than ever and impresses at first glance, as always, but it quickly becomes just a repetitive sequence of corridors while you zigzag from one point to another to simply watch cutscenes‚Äîwhile occasionally, once again to pretend there‚Äôs some gameplay between scenes, your path is interrupted by generic enemies attacking you randomly in the street.

It‚Äôs just so‚Ä¶ bad. So, [i]so[/i] bad. The narrative design of this game is horrendous. The mission design (if you can call it that) is even worse.

Which leads me to the realization, after all these years, that this series is just a one-trick pony. Impressive as a whole when it‚Äôs new and still has interesting stories to tell, but one that quickly reveals itself to be formulaic and unable to evolve its experience beyond the stagnation present in the titles from recent years.

No matter how brilliant the new effects and animations are, how well they‚Äôve balanced stylization and realism in the graphics, or how refined the formula becomes, it still feels like you‚Äôre playing a game stuck in PS2-era conventions.

Maybe things get better later on, but the price of admission‚Äîas often happens with these narrative-driven Japanese games stretched to extremes‚Äîis simply pure boredom.

Most of my time with the game was spent going from point A to point B to watch cutscenes, then going to point C to watch more, then back to A to watch even more. Cutscenes that, for the most part, are redundant, delivering information about a barely engaging murder mystery, with no personal involvement for the characters beyond some shallow idealism from the protagonist.

It may be detailed and presented with cinematography that makes watching them a bit more tolerable. And the franchise is quite notorious for dumping highly drawn-out exposition bombs on the player. But it doesn‚Äôt change the fact that the game doesn‚Äôt even feel like it has started after all this time.

I didn‚Äôt even have the opportunity to actually enjoy the combat, shallow as it is.

So, at this point, I can‚Äôt recommend the game to anyone. Not to newcomers looking for a good entry point, nor to veterans wanting to check out what this story and these new characters are about.

If you‚Äôre not willing to waste at least 10 hours with practically nothing meaningful happening and an immensely mediocre gameplay experience, I‚Äôd say don‚Äôt even go near it.

I‚Äôll keep trying in the next few days, hoping for a hook that justifies the money spent, but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs going to work this time.

I honestly cannot see why people recommend this game. Also, the waiting for simple phone calls makes this even MORE of a slog than it already was. And the combat is hyper janky for no reason. Keep in mind, I have played every Yakuza game on Steam (at the time of this review, I'm aware Kiwami 3 is coming out) before this and LJ, so I have a pretty good idea on the other combat styles from the previous games I played. Not only that, the "stuffing side quests down your throat" is way more impeding that you'd think, and it's much of the same issue I had with Ishin Kiwami, where every corner you turned in that game, you'd be dragged into a side quest. There's a reason why only SOME skills are locked behind that stuff in other games, save for the entirety of Dragon in Kiwami. If you REALLY have to play this game, get it on a very low sale. Otherwise, don't bother.

Edit: I'm going to revise this review. Not because I change my mind... but because I vastly underestimated this game in terms of shittiness. I'll continue to play only because I want to beat every Yakuza game, but I'm not impressed. Doubling down, the side cases this game shoves down your throat... are some of the most bland and boring garbage I've ever seen. It's like RGG wanted to pad out the game time, but couldn't think of anything interesting. Substories are generally goofy, but these are not only so annoying when they crop up, they're not even charming or goofy. They add nothing to the story and feel like last-minute decisions. At least with Ishin, you have the option to not take part of the substories. Here? Fuck you, go solve a "mystery" on who ate your former co-worker's cake, only for it to be nobody because everyone in the room has room temperature IQ, and thus wasting everyone's time including the player's. There's even a side case where if you say no to doing it, they just take the option away from you. Yes, they lump it in with the main story. Thanks, RGG. Fuck you for that.

The gang. I can not be bothered to give a shit about their name, but all I will say is... I thought Yakuza 5 was the worst contender of enemy encounters. I thought wrong. This gang serves no purpose other than to, again, needlessly pad out game time.

I look forward to finishing this game. Not because I'm invested, but so I can get it over with and play Lost Judgment, closing the book on this series until Y3K comes out.

Final Revise: I've finished the game, finally. And sadly, the negatives outweigh the positives too much for me to consider this a good game. Where the game has one good aspect, two more underlying problems arise. Story gets going at the end... but only at the end. As in, "Chapters 12 and 13" end. The final two chapters. Keihin gang has a good theme and the bosses are interesting characters. Kim, the sniper rifle sight of the grunts, and having to navigate Kamurocho like a maze with spawns worse than Y5 make it frustrating to even enjoy that aspect, among other things. Side cases unnecessarily clogging up the story, with Chapter 4 being the absolute worst contender at FOUR SIDE CASES IN ONE CHAPTER. Lack of direction or hints toward solving objectives that the player wouldn't know without having played this game prior, with Chapter 8 being the worst contender. Tiger Style, Crane Style and the restrictive locks for half of the game's entire skill catalogue behind skill books and QR codes.

No matter how you slice it, this is truly, as someone else put it, the Y3 of the dragon engine, made all the more ironic by the fact that a Y3K is coming out as I type this review. I feel like the only reason it's as well received as it is is because it just so happened to come out after the messes that were Y6 and Y2K. And from a technical standpoint, this game IS an improvement from those games. However, that "improvement" isn't exactly a high bar from those games, and like them, still has a lot of problems. At least Y2K has the Silly Mod. I do not think I'll be playing this game ever again, unless I suppress these memories of me playing it.

That being said, Dice and Cube was probably one of the few aspects of the game where I genuinely had fun. Sadly, the negatives still outweigh the positives, so even that doesn't save it.

Protagonist is bland and a creep (35yo dating a 19yo), only two combat styles and one is pretty pointless. Tracks enemies poorly, wall moves are tempermental,  enemies can kill you in two hits, and the Mortal Wounds system is stupid. Almost nonexistent XP rewards for doing anything meaning massive grinding is needed.  Not able to make any money from fighting either, so the vast majority of your xp and cash has to come from FUCKING MINIGAMES which are either RNG based, or involve the AI just cheating its ass off.   

Then there's the side quests.. FUCK THE SIDE QUESTS.  You'll get quests interrupting quests interrupting quests, all being interrupted by a gang popping up over and over and forcing you into fights every ten seconds, which would be fine for grinding IF YOU GOT ANY WORTHWHILE XP FROM IT.  So much in the game is designed to waste your time, delay you, and generally just pad out the game time with bullshit.  

Want XP to upgrade your character?  Well you gotta make money and do a bunch of side quests to get passes to play a dice game to make even more money, enough to buy some drinks that give you xp but for those to be really effective they have to be paired with XP boosting extracts, which means MORE side quests and scavenging.  Wanna not bother with that and grind XP the good old fashioned way (beating people up)?  You get 9xp per person you knock out.  The amount of XP you need to START upgrading your stats and abilities is 1000.  You need to beat up over 100 guys just to get a small increase to your health bar (which can be taken away in an instant because of the mortal wound system).  For higher levelling up you need 18000 XP.  Plus you need to spend a good amount of XP just to make other side quests (to do other side quests) doable without looking up guides.  Want drone parts for the races?  Well you gotta find small QR codes scattered around the map on buildings, so you can either run around town looking at every wall on every building trying to find them, or you can spend a bunch of XP and money on getting abilities to have an easier time finding the codes, and that's XP that you'd rather spend on stuff like health, speed, and power.  Oh well, guess you'll have to grind EVEN MORE to get those now.  And if you do get those top tier drone parts you'll still have to put up with rubber banding AI that will fly past you in the last five seconds of a race.

There are NO weapons or items that help your stats (like any kind of armour), only the extract system for a variety of small temporary boosts, and those extracts require running around looking for components to make them with.

Also hope you like walking slow and ducking behind cover because there's a LOT of tailing missions.  

So what in this game isn't dogshit? The story.  It's not great but it's not bad, even if it is pretty predictable and needs better pacing.

If you HAVE to play a Judgement game, get the second one.  The story isn't as good, but everything else in it is a significant improvement over this one.

The amount of XP you need to START upgrading your stats and abilities is 1000.  You need to beat up over 100 guys just to get a small increase to your health bar (which can be taken away in an instant because of the mortal wound system).  For higher levelling up you need 18000 XP.  Plus you need to spend a good amount of XP just to make other side quests (to do other side quests) doable without looking up guides.  Want drone parts for the races?  Well you gotta find small QR codes scattered around the map on buildings, so you can either run around town looking at every wall on every building trying to find them, or you can spend a bunch of XP and money on getting abilities to have an easier time finding the codes, and that's XP that you'd rather spend on stuff like health, speed, and power.  Oh well, guess you'll have to grind EVEN MORE to get those now.  And if you do get those top tier drone parts you'll still have to put up with rubber banding AI that will fly past you in the last five seconds of a race.

There are NO weapons or items that help your stats (like any kind of armour), only the extract system for a variety of small temporary boosts, and those extracts require running around looking for components to make them with.

Also hope you like walking slow and ducking behind cover because there's a LOT of tailing missions.  

So what in this game isn't dogshit? The story.  It's not great but it's not bad, even if it is pretty predictable and needs better pacing.
